title: Rock covered with Moss and Lichen

questions.questionText: What living things can you see growing on this rock?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies moss and describes it with specific details (color, texture, or location on rock) and may mention other organisms like leaves or insects.
rubric.meets: Student correctly identifies moss as a living thing growing on the rock.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies something growing on the rock but is uncertain whether it is living, or describes it with vague language.
rubric.beginning: Student gives a minimal response or is unable to identify any living things on the rock.

questions.questionText: How do you think the moss gets what it needs to live on this rock?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that moss gets water from rain and nutrients from the air or decaying material, showing understanding of multiple needs for plant survival.
rubric.meets: Student explains that moss gets water or moisture from the rock or ground, or mentions that it gets what it needs from its surroundings.
rubric.approaching: Student mentions one way moss gets what it needs but explanation is incomplete or partially unclear (e.g., 'it gets water' without explaining where from).
rubric.beginning: Student provides a vague guess or incorrect explanation about how moss survives on the rock.

questions.questionText: What might happen to this rock if it stayed outside for many more years?

rubric.exceeds: Student predicts that the rock will break down or change shape and explains that moss, weather, or roots may cause it to crumble or become smaller over time.
rubric.meets: Student predicts the rock will change or break down over time, mentioning weathering, moss growth, or similar cause.
rubric.approaching: Student makes a prediction about change but explanation lacks clear connection to weathering or biological processes.
rubric.beginning: Student provides minimal or vague prediction with little reasoning about what might happen to the rock.

questions.questionText: How is this rock similar to and different from the rocks in our school playground?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple similarities (shape, hardness, size) and differences (moss coverage, color, location/moisture) and explains why differences exist based on environment.
rubric.meets: Student identifies at least one similarity and one difference between the forest rock and playground rocks accurately.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies a similarity or difference but description is vague, or identifies only one comparison without the other.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a minimal attempt to compare rocks or provides inaccurate observations.
